bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas, November 6, 1940

div1.p: Hench describes the Lazear memorial ceremony at Washington and Jefferson College and sends her a clipping. He believes that the Camp Lazear memorial and preservation of Building No. 1 will be carried out successfully.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas, November 6, 1940
div1.p:
I cannot tell you how very pleased I was to receive the cable from you,
and all the good members of your family, at Washington Pennsylvania. It was indeed
a thoughtful gesture on your part.

The dedication of the Lazear Memorial Building was very fine. The ceremony
was most dignified and impressive, and the building is a beautiful one. There was
quite a crowd there, and my talk at the banquet Saturday evening was most sympathetically
received. Three relatives of Dr. Lazear were present and were so interested in all
that I had to say. I have also heard from Mrs. Lazear, who expressed a great interest
in all that was done, including the discovery of Camp Lazear. I am sending you a
clipping from the local paper. I am leaving tomorrow on a medical speaking trip for
about ten days, and as soon as I can, I wish to have my paper submitted for publica-
tion in a medical journal. There will be no trouble at all in having it accepted
and I will see that you and your relatives have reprints as a permanent memorandum.
Several present were most interested in my little campaign to purchase the building
and memorialize the various sites involved, and I am sure that we can conclude this
venture successfully. On my return, I will write you further details of this plan.

General Kean (the Major Kean mentioned in your husband's day book) was de-
lighted with our discovery and most interested to know of your finding of the records.
That is practically the last proof that we need except that I asked Mr. Moran to get
a photostatic copy of Mr. Zunzunegei's 1907 contract and also of the previous contract
made before the two little wooden buildings were mentioned.
Mrs. Hench and I send to you and yours our very warmest greetings.
div1.closer: Hastily but very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
